title: Widespread failure of certificate validation in Android apps
vulnerability_information:
I have identified approximately 75 Android applications (and some iPad) that fail to validate SSL certificates, either failing to validate valid certificate authorities, correct hostnames or both.

I have made attempts to responsibly disclose all of these vulns to the responsible parties. A few have been omitted from this list for various reasons.

Almost all of these could have lead to credit card and/or password disclosure.

activities.message: @atrummer - That list is incredible, and it's reasonable to assume it is not exhaustive. My personal stance is that individual disclosure here is an excessive burden on you given that so many of these apps do not advertise a vulnerability disclosure process. Have you performed any analysis into the root cause of the underlying implementation issues here? I'd prefer to see any public disclosure to be accompanied by a summary of common Android implementation errors for developers to review themselves.

activities.message:
I have no intention of any public disclosure of specific apps at this time and have been told by my employer not to go to the press about it, but I spoke to CERT and US-CERT again yesterday and gave them the gist. I will forward them a similar list later today in hopes they can handle coordinated disclosures.

I have not attempted to determine the exact root cause for each, although I eluded to one possible cause in a related blog post a few months ago (http://securityglitch.blogspot.com/2013/12/webview-insecurity.html) that discussed how developers can disable this in WebViews.  

As far as I know, it's usually caused by developers turning it off during testing, because they don't want to deal with certificate warnings.  After we found these issues, my boss pointed out a whitepaper (http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~shmat/shmat_ccs12.pdf) from two years ago, that is a must-read on the subject. 

If you go to www.themeninthemiddle.com ( or tmitm) you can see more details on testing for this.

Spent some time discussing but unfortunately don't believe it fits the eligibility of the program, primarily given the numerous underlying causes and the shared independent discoveries.
